Signed-off-by: Freyskeyd <simon.paitrault@gmail.com>

title: Use std::collections::HashMap instead of hashbrown
body:
Split from #265 

`std::collections::HashMap`'s implementation has been replaced with `hashbrown::HashMap` implementation in Rust 1.36. Using `std::collections::HashMap` is good because we can reduce dependency.

`hashbrown 0.3.0` uses `fx` algorithm:
> This hash function is very fast for all types of keys, but this algorithm will typically not protect against attacks such as HashDoS.

`std::collections::HashMap` uses `SipHash`:
> While its performance is very competitive for medium sized keys, other hashing algorithms will outperform it for small keys such as integers as well as large keys such as long strings, though those algorithms will typically not protect against attacks such as HashDoS.

I am in favor of using std's default algorithm, but other opinions are welcome.

title: Add Context::connected
body:
If an actor registers an event, the actor does not stop when all addresses to it get dropped.
This behavior is not desirable in some cases like an actor periodically polls an expensive API and works as a cache.
This PR adds `connected` method to `Context`, which allows spawned future to check whether there is an alive address to the actor and to stop it when there is none.

title: Loosen type bounds on Actor::create
body:
Currently, `Actor::create` requires that the constructor function satisfies `F: 'static`. 

This was required at first due to the function being called within a spawned future. It first became unnecessary at 12dbad838d92c2a48d01b9cd14192f7f3c887ca0 when `Actor::create` [moved away from that](https://github.com/actix/actix/commit/12dbad838d92c2a48d01b9cd14192f7f3c887ca0#diff-49f917dedc0c847aa6e201bcf53b8143R156), calling the new `Context::create` which [retained the stricter bounds](https://github.com/actix/actix/commit/12dbad838d92c2a48d01b9cd14192f7f3c887ca0#diff-e0934bb6f70a4f8c3baf22a773c14ec7R98) even though the function was now called and dropped within the scope of the call to `create`. 

Not much has changed since then, except in 78455a43d3a7ac696e9e29eb9652002a627d1f62 where `Context::create` was removed and its contents [factored into `Actor::create`](https://github.com/actix/actix/commit/78455a43d3a7ac696e9e29eb9652002a627d1f62#diff-49f917dedc0c847aa6e201bcf53b8143R153).

title: Add must_use to FutureActor and FutureStream
body:
Closes https://github.com/actix/actix/issues/259

I didn't specifically write a test for it (testing for the existence of a warning is really annoying) but I did verify it myself by messing with an existing test:
```
warning: unused `actix::fut::map_err::MapErr` that must be used
  --> tests/test_fut.rs:23:9
   |
23 | /         Delay::new(Instant::now() + Duration::new(0, 5_000_000))
24 | |             .then(|_| {
25 | |                 System::current().stop();
26 | |                 Ok::<_, Error>(())
...  |
35 | |                 }
36 | |             });
   | |_______________^
   |
   = note: #[warn(unused_must_use)] on by default
   = note: futures do nothing unless polled
```

title: Add `std::error::Error` implementation for `MailboxError`
body:
Since `MailboxError` does not have an underlying error which caused
it, and the `std::error::Error::description()` method is
soft-deprecated ("new `impl`s can omit it", to quote the standard
library), an empty implementation suffices.

title: Add actix::io::SinkWrite<Sink>: A `Sink` IO wrapper
body:
A `futures::sink::Sink` wrapper for writing messages into a stream
from within a Actor. It allows more the use of custom sink objects
(or the use of channels).

It's an addition to `actix::io::FramedWrite<AsyncWrite, Encoder>`
and `actix::io::Writer<AsyncWrite>`. Both of those induce copies
into the inner buffer that can be sometime avoid with custom sink.

title: Improve example for `ActorFuture`
body:
I felt the example was a little lacking when learning about it, so I think the more explicit comments are helpful here. I also removed a syntax error.

Personally, I think this example is a little too complicated to get the point across. It's somewhat unclear where `ActorFuture` even comes in. The fact that we `send` at all is unnecessary and I would have preferred to use a more generic `Future` to demonstrate that the point of `ActorFuture` is just to add `Actor` data to a `Future` (which has little to nothing to do directly with `send`ing, as far as I can tell).

title: Fix compiler warning because of doc comment in the wrong place
body:
Recently rustdoc started issuing compiler warnings for doc comments above macro expansions. Moving this comment inside the macro resolves that. However, this comment still doesn't show up in the documentation, because the struct in question is not publicly reachable. 

So for consistency I remove the pub. As an alternative, it might be `pub( crate )`. Please modify to your liking.

`cargo test --all-features` runs fine. As some extra test I thought I run all tests on actix-web as well, but I can't get actix-web to compile with a local actix, so ... dunno... 

ps: I'm using nightly compiler

title: Bump trust-dns-proto to 0.6
body:
Currently actix ends up pulling both 0.5 and 0.6:
```
trust-dns-proto v0.5.0
└── actix v0.7.10 (/home/fabrice/dev/actix)

trust-dns-proto v0.6.3
└── trust-dns-resolver v0.10.3
    └── actix v0.7.10 (/home/fabrice/dev/actix)
```
Moving to 0.6 prevents that.

title: Improve the wording of public API documentation
body:
This commit results from proof-reading the API docs throughout the
whole crate, excluding the `fut` module and its children.

Mostly, the changes are in the following areas:

- Use a consistent style, which is also used by the standard
  library, for example:

  - Using just "Registers ..." instead instead of "This method
    registers" for functions.

  - Use punctiation more consistently (no full stops in headings, but
    about everywhere else).

- Missing articles and other minor stylistic issues.

- Some markup issues (e.g. missing backticks for identifiers).

Besides mere wording improvements, which I hope are indeed
improvements (I'm not a native speaker, but dare to say that I'm quite
confident in English), the following tweaks also were made along the
way:

- Export the `Builder` type from the private `arbiter` module, after
  renaming it to `ArbiterBuilder`. Previously, this type was not
  directly visible from outside the crate, and thus also missing from
  `cargo doc` output.

- Adjust a few copy-pasted error strings in `AsyncContext`.

title: Revise Registry comments and examples
body:
I removed `MyActor1.start()` from the `SystemRegistry` example, as there would otherwise be two `MyActor1`'s running (since `MyActor2` starts a `MyActor1` when it tries to get `MyActor1` from the registry).

I also fixed some grammar/spelling and removed some extra lines.

title: Updating trust-dns-resolver dependency to version 0.10.
body:
trust-dns-resolver 0.10.0 has additional, useful options (e.g., max TTL) that can be passed in via ResolverOpts. These newer options are not available in trust-dns-resolver 0.9.1, which is what Actix currently depends on. This pull request updates Actix to depend on trust-dns-resolver 0.10.

What trust-dns-resolver used to call ResolverFuture is now called AsyncResolver. When creating an AsyncResolver, instead of being given a Future which must be waited on to construct the Resolver, you are immediately given an AsyncResolver, plus a background task that must be spawned to perform DNS lookups (https://docs.rs/trust-dns-resolver/0.10.0/trust_dns_resolver/struct.AsyncResolver.html). This pull request essentially does the renaming of types, plus spawns the background task.

title: fix infinite loop in ContextFut::poll() caused by late cancel_future()
body:
Canceled handles are generally consumed in the "process items" loop, but
the loop never runs if there's no item to process. As a result, the handles
are left unprocessed and the 'outer loop never resolves. This patch addresses
the issue by discarding the canceled handles if there's no item still alive.

The test case is a bit hairy. It wouldn't finish without the fix. I couldn't
come up with a better idea.

title: Expose API for custom SyncArbiter
body: I'm writing a specialized SyncArbiter. This exposes the private APIs that are needed to move src/sync.rs into a separate crate.

title: Correct spelling

title: Use tokio_timer's Clock abstraction
body:
Tokio's `Registry` allows to set a custom `Clock` instance, which makes it possible to mock all timer related functions in tests. This PR adds the option to set that clock in the `System`'s runtime as well as override it in each `Arbiter`.

There is now `System::builder()`, which allows to set that clock instance and then build a `SystemRunner`. The type level docs have an example for that. It is not publicly exported, just like the Arbiter builder is not exported. Let me know, if you'd like to change that.

To make `Clock`, `Now` (the trait behind it) and `clock::now()` more accessible, this PR also adds a new public `actix::clock` module which contains a basic re-export of `tokio_timer::clock`. That way, users do not have to explicitly add `tokio_timer` to their own crate's dependencies.

It could also make sense to re-export more stuff from `tokio_timer`, like for instance `Delay`. In that case, I would propose renaming that module to `actix::timer`. Also, `utils::TimerFunc` could belong in that module, if you choose to make it available (see #136).

For now, I did not bother to use a mock clock in tests, but that might be a logical addition. Just let me know if you'd like me to update them.

Fixes #136
